PSU Statistics School
By Elijah Bernstein-Cooper, June 2, 2015, 0 comments.

I’ve been attending the Penn State University Summer School for Statistics. Here is the program. I’ve highlighted a few key points from some of the lectures.

Maximum Likelihood Estimation

Today we learned about maximum likelihood estimation from Kwame Kankam. See the lecture. A few take away points:

  • is a biased estimator.

  • variance of 1/B where B is the Fisher information matrix.

  • There is only loss of information when binning with MLE. This probably assumes that all points are i.i.d.

Parametric models should not be used to only summarize the relationship of variables. Nonparametric models

When using MCMCs:

  • use several different algorithms

  • use different starting points, run several times

I talked with Jogesh Babu about my application of MLE. He mentioned that for a random variable with observations , the joint probability will be

However we do not know the conditional probabilities, e.g., $$f(x_2 x_1)$$.

Perhaps instead of binning we should smooth the data with a kernel, and include knowledge of the conditional probabilities given the smoothed data.
